study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of preconception iron and folic acid (IFA) or multiple micronutrients (MMs) supplementation on offspring intellectual functioning at age 6-7 years compared to folic acid (FA) alone.
results_summary: Offspring in the MM group showed higher full-scale IQ (FSIQ), working memory (WMI), and processing speed (PSI) scores compared to the FA group, with no significant differences in verbal comprehension (VCI) or perceptual reasoning (PRI). Similar results were observed in per-protocol analyses.
population_specificity: Women in Vietnam and their offspring (n=1321 at follow-up).
effective_dosage: 60 mg iron and 2800 μg folic acid weekly (IFA group) or multiple micronutrients (including IFA) weekly.
study_duration: From baseline until conception, followed by daily prenatal IFA until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent studies on iron metabolism in infants and evaluate the risks and benefits of iron supplementation in different populations.
results_summary: The study found that iron deficiency negatively impacts neurodevelopment, but iron overload may cause adverse effects like diarrhea and poor neurodevelopment. Delayed cord clamping and targeted supplementation for at-risk infants were beneficial, while iron supplementation for pregnant women showed limited effects on offspring iron status and neurodevelopment.
population_specificity: Infants, including normal birth weight and low birth weight infants, and pregnant women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a pillbox for increasing iron supplement compliance among pregnant women attending antenatal care (ANC).
results_summary: The study found that the proportion of pregnant women with no remaining iron tablets was significantly higher in the pillbox group (53.3%) compared to the control group (23.1%), indicating improved compliance with iron supplementation.
population_specificity: Pregnant women attending ANC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of iron and folic acid (IFA) supplementation on maternal hypertension and its associations with birth outcomes compared to other nutrient supplements.
results_summary: The study found that daily provision of iron and folic acid (IFA) did not affect maternal hypertension compared to other supplements. Higher diastolic blood pressure (DBP) was associated with lower birth weight and shorter gestation, increasing the risk of low birth weight and preterm birth.
population_specificity: Pregnant Ghanaian women at ≤20 weeks of gestation (n = 1320).
effective_dosage: Daily iron and folic acid (IFA) supplementation (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of Mastiha (not Iron) as a nonpharmacological intervention in patients with NAFLD, assessing its impact on liver inflammation, fibrosis, microbiota dysbiosis, and lipid metabolites.
results_summary: Mastiha supplementation improved microbiota dysbiosis and lipid metabolite levels in NAFLD patients but only reduced liver inflammation/fibrosis parameters in severely obese patients (BMI ≤ 35 kg/m²). It was not superior to placebo in the overall population for cT1 and LIF scores.
population_specificity: Patients with NAFLD from Greece, Italy, and Serbia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-iron MNP (5 mg iron) versus standard MNP (12.5 mg iron) on gut microbiota composition in Bangladeshi children exposed to iron-rich groundwater.
results_summary: The study found no significant overall treatment effect of low-iron MNP compared to standard MNP on gut microbiota. However, a non-significant trend suggested higher relative abundance of potentially pathogenic Enterobacteriaceae in children with adult-like microbiota after standard MNP use.
population_specificity: 2- to 5-year-old Bangladeshi children drinking groundwater with high iron concentration (≥ 2 mg/L).
effective_dosage: One sachet per day of either standard MNP (12.5 mg iron) or low-iron MNP (5 mg iron).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intravenous iron therapy (ferric derisomaltose) improves peak oxygen consumption in heart transplant recipients with low iron stores.
results_summary: Intravenous iron did not significantly improve peak oxygen consumption overall, but it did show benefit in patients with baseline ferritin <30 µg/liter. Iron stores were restored in most treated patients, and quality of life improved significantly compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Heart transplant recipients with serum ferritin <100 µg/liter or 100-300 µg/liter plus transferrin saturation <20%, enrolled ≥1 year post-transplant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence, clinical characteristics, and adherence to ESC guidelines for iron deficiency (ID) and iron supplementation (IS) in heart failure (HF) patients in real-world clinical practice.
results_summary: The study found that only one-third of HF patients were tested for ID, with 33.9% of those tested diagnosed. Among HFrEF patients with ID, only 39.3% received intravenous IS as recommended, highlighting suboptimal guideline adherence.
population_specificity: Adult patients with heart failure (HF), including inpatients and outpatients, with acute or chronic HF, predominantly male (69.3%) and median age 69 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the timing of micronutrient supplementation (including iron) during pregnancy affects the incidence of pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH).
results_summary: Early initiation (before 12 weeks) of multiple micronutrient (MMN) supplementation significantly reduced the incidence of PIH compared to later initiation, with protective effects observed for both early- and late-onset PIH. No significant association was found for iron-folic acid (IFA) or folic acid (FA) alone.
population_specificity: 18,775 nulliparous pregnant women with mild or no anaemia, enrolled at ≤20 weeks of gestation in northern China.
effective_dosage: Daily supplementation (specific amounts not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative iron supplementation improves postoperative hemoglobin levels and other outcomes in total joint arthroplasty patients.
results_summary: Postoperative oral iron had no effect on hemoglobin levels, while intravenous iron increased hemoglobin levels and reduced anemia rates at 30 days post-surgery. No adverse events were reported, and intravenous iron improved quality of life in severely anemic patients compared to oral iron.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ undergoing elective total joint arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to revise the understanding of female physiology, focusing on the interaction between reproductive hormones (oestrogen and progesterone) and iron homeostasis, and to identify potential periods for nutritional iron supplementation during the menstrual cycle.
results_summary: The review highlights a symbiotic relationship between iron metabolism and the menstrual cycle, suggesting that female athletes may require more frequent iron screening due to higher prevalence of iron deficiency, potentially linked to menstrual cycles. It identifies areas of the menstrual cycle that may benefit from iron supplementation but calls for additional research.
population_specificity: Female athletes, particularly premenopausal, with a focus on those with a history of iron deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between iron levels and poor prognostic factors in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: Low iron levels were associated with poor prognostic factors in COVID-19 patients, suggesting a potential role in disease severity. The study highlights the importance of monitoring and addressing iron deficiency in COVID-19 management.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients over 18 years of age admitted to Ankara City Hospital between March and June 2020.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of iron and other micronutrients in preventing or alleviating COVID-19 severity, particularly in populations with deficiencies.
results_summary: The study found that deficiencies in iron and other micronutrients are common among vulnerable populations and COVID-19 patients, potentially increasing mortality risk, and suggested that need-based supplementation could be beneficial.
population_specificity: Vulnerable populations, particularly in low- and middle-income countries, and COVID-19 patients with micronutrient deficiencies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of roxadustat, an oral HIF-PHD inhibitor, in treating anemia in CKD patients compared to traditional treatments like iron, vitamin B12, and folic acid supplementation.
results_summary: Roxadustat was found to be more effective than previously used drugs in stimulating erythropoiesis for anemia correction in CKD patients, with the added advantage of oral administration. The exact role of roxadustat in iron metabolism and cardiovascular risk remains unclear.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), both with and without dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of iron homeostasis in cancer-related anemia (CRA) and propose an integrated approach involving nutrition and exercise to improve iron utilization.
results_summary: The study highlights that CRA involves complex iron dysregulation due to chronic inflammation, with hepcidin playing a key role. It suggests a Mediterranean-based diet, supplements, and exercise as complementary strategies to conventional CRA therapy.
population_specificity: Cancer patients with anemia (CRA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of iron deficiency (ID) in anemia among HIV-infected and uninfected children, and whether iron supplementation recommendations should differ for HIV-infected children.
results_summary: The study found that iron deficiency prevalence was similar in HIV-infected and uninfected children, suggesting no need for different iron supplementation recommendations. HIV-infected children had a reduced risk of malaria but comparable levels of iron deficiency.
population_specificity: Mozambican children aged 1-59 months with documented HIV status (390 anemic, 272 non-anemic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha lipoic acid (ALA) supplementation could reduce iron levels (serum ferritin), improve lipid profiles, and decrease oxidative stress in β-thalassemia major (β-TM) patients.
results_summary: ALA supplementation significantly reduced serum ferritin and malondialdehyde (MDA) levels while increasing HDL-C, but it had no significant effects on other biomarkers. The effect on serum ferritin was more pronounced in women.
population_specificity: 26 β-thalassemia major (β-TM) patients (22 completed the study).
study_duration: 8 weeks per intervention phase, with a 21-day washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of preoperative iron supplementation as an alternative to allogeneic red blood cell transfusions in cancer patients undergoing surgery.
results_summary: The study suggests that preoperative iron supplementation may be advantageous in cases where transfusions are limited or not desired, though specific efficacy data on iron alone is not detailed. The abstract implies potential benefits but lacks direct evidence or statistical outcomes for iron supplementation.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing surgical resection of primary solid tumours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the micronutrient supply and deficiencies, including iron, in mothers with multiple pregnancies.
results_summary: The study found that women with multiple pregnancies might be at risk of iron deficiencies, but evidence for other micronutrients was inconsistent or scarce.
population_specificity: Mothers with multiple pregnancies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative intravenous iron supplementation reduces the need for allogeneic blood transfusions and increases hemoglobin levels in patients with preoperative anemia.
results_summary: Preoperative IV iron supplementation significantly reduced blood transfusions by 16% and increased hemoglobin levels both preoperatively and postoperatively, without increasing adverse effects compared to placebo or oral iron.
population_specificity: Patients with preoperative anemia requiring surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of different iron treatments on FGF23 levels in CKD patients with iron deficiency anemia.
results_summary: Iron treatment significantly reduced FGF23 levels in CKD patients, with oral iron therapy showing greater effectiveness than intravenous iron therapy. No significant change was observed in cFGF23 levels overall, though oral iron therapy did reduce cFGF23 levels significantly compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Dialysis-dependent and non-dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients with iron deficiency anemia (IDA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the role of food supplements, including iron, in addressing nutrient deficiencies and reducing the risk of chronic diseases.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that food supplements, including iron, can help address inadequate nutrient intake and potentially reduce the risk of chronic diseases, though higher intakes than typical dietary levels may be needed for optimal health benefits.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mention of ageing populations and groups with inadequate nutrient intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the regulatory effects of iron and other transition metal ions on gut microbiota, considering both deficiency and supplementation.
results_summary: The study summarized findings from multiple animal and human studies, indicating that iron has regulatory effects on gut microbiota, though specific outcomes varied based on deficiency or supplementation. Mechanisms behind these effects were also discussed.
population_specificity: Animal models and human studies (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine policy measures and program implementation to reduce anemia attributed to iron deficiency in Indonesia.
results_summary: The study found that iron-folic acid (IFA) supplementation programs faced implementation challenges, including inadequate supply, insufficient facilities, and lack of follow-up. National fortification using wheat flour was limited in effectiveness across Indonesia.
population_specificity: Indonesian population, particularly focusing on anemia prevention programs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of roxadustat, an oral HIF prolyl hydroxylase inhibitor, in treating anemia in kidney disease patients with or without dialysis.
results_summary: Roxadustat significantly increased hemoglobin levels, total iron-binding capacity, and iron levels while reducing hepcidin and ferritin levels. No significant differences were found in adverse events, serious adverse events, or other complications compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Kidney disease patients with or without dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether weekly iron and folic acid supplementation (WIFAS) could reduce neural tube defects (NTDs) and inform potential inclusion in the WHO Model Essential Medicines List (MEML).
results_summary: The study found that WIFAS reduced anemia, but evidence on folic acid's efficacy for NTD prevention was insufficient at the time of the last review. A recent trial assessed different folic acid dosages to address this gap.
population_specificity: 331 women aged 18-45 years.
effective_dosage: 60 mg Fe as ferrous fumarate with 0 mg, 0.4 mg, or 2.8 mg folic acid, consumed once weekly.
study_duration: 16 weeks of supplementation followed by a 4-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers sought to understand the impediments to resolving nutritional anemia in Indonesian children and adolescents, focusing on iron-deficient anemia.
results_summary: The review identified gaps in addressing anemia, particularly in remote and rural areas, and highlighted three intervention approaches (food-based, supplementation, and education) that showed some progress but lacked comprehensive evaluation of causality and comorbidities.
population_specificity: Indonesian children and adolescents, primarily in school settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nutritional contributors to anemia during pregnancy in Indonesia, including the role of iron supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that inadequate iron supplementation was not significantly associated with maternal anemia, while chronic energy deficiency, greater parity, low education level, and limited health knowledge were significant risk factors.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Indonesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how reducing iron content and adding bovine lactoferrin to infant formula affects iron status, health, and development.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the modified formula on iron status, health, or development.
population_specificity: Swedish healthy full-term formula-fed infants.
effective_dosage: Iron content in infant formula was reduced from 8-14 mg/L (standard fortification) to an unspecified lower level, with added bovine lactoferrin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether blood donors in Ghana could recover their iron stores five months after donating a single unit of whole blood without routine iron supplementation.
results_summary: Five months post-donation, 76.8% of donors failed to recover pre-donation iron stores, with increased rates of depleted iron stores (9.8%) and iron-deficient erythropoiesis (21.3%). Additionally, 11% of donors would have been disqualified from donating again due to low hemoglobin levels.
population_specificity: Blood donors from three communities (Lawra, Nandom, Bimbila) in northern Ghana.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a pragmatic approach for clinicians to diagnose iron deficiency and decide on iron supplementation, including choosing between oral and parenteral administration.
results_summary: The study highlights the challenges in diagnosing iron deficiency due to inflammation-related markers and offers guidance for personalized treatment decisions when patients do not fit standard guidelines.
population_specificity: Patients with conditions causing low-grade inflammation, such as chronic kidney disease, cirrhosis, or heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of SQ-LNSs (containing iron and other nutrients) on maternal and child health outcomes in Sub-Saharan Africa, including growth, development, and iron/hemoglobin status.
results_summary: Prenatal SQ-LNS consumption reduced low gestational weight gain in Ghana but was associated with poorer iron/hemoglobin status compared to iron-plus-folic acid supplementation. SQ-LNSs improved child growth in some trials (Ghana, Burkina Faso, Kenya, Zimbabwe, South Africa) but not in Malawi, and enhanced motor development in multiple countries without affecting other developmental domains.
population_specificity: Pregnant/lactating women and children ≥6 months old in Sub-Saharan Africa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the safety of different intravenous iron formulations for treating iron deficiency anemia in IBD patients.
results_summary: The study found that intravenous iron supplementation is the most effective therapy for IBD-associated iron deficiency anemia, though gastrointestinal side effects are common with oral iron. Clinicians' perception of risk with intravenous administration may limit its use despite its efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with active inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and iron deficiency anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of iron deficiency, its consequences, and the effectiveness of oral and parenteral iron therapies in treating iron deficiency and anemia.
results_summary: The study found that iron deficiency significantly contributes to global disease burden, particularly affecting children, premenopausal women, and individuals in low-income countries. Oral iron therapy is effective but limited by hepcidin upregulation, while modern parenteral iron formulations offer safe, rapid total-dose replacement.
population_specificity: Children, premenopausal women, and people in low-income and middle-income countries; men and postmenopausal women with iron deficiency anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence, clinical significance, and risk factors for medication-related problems (MRPs), particularly focusing on iron supplementation among hospitalized pregnant or postpartum women.
results_summary: The study found that lack of iron supplementation was the most common medication-related problem, affecting 28.9% of participants, with 70.6% of MRPs considered moderate to high clinical significance. Improved adherence to iron supplementation guidelines was recommended to address these issues.
population_specificity: Hospitalized pregnant or postpartum women in the maternity and gynecology wards at Jimma University Medical Centre in Ethiopia.

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of intra-operative administration of iron isomaltoside for preventing postoperative anaemia in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found that intra-operative iron isomaltoside significantly reduced the incidence of anaemia at 30 days post-surgery (34.1% vs. 62.2% in the control group) and improved haemoglobin, serum ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled for unilateral total knee arthroplasty (n=89).
effective_dosage: 1136 ± 225 mg of iron isomaltoside administered intravenously.
study_duration: Single dose administered during surgical wound closure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the micronutrient status (including iron) of women in their reproductive years and during pregnancy across seven Asian regions, assessing associated health consequences and dietary causes.
results_summary: The study found that micronutrient deficiencies, particularly iron-related anemia, are common among Asian women of reproductive age, with inadequate dietary intake and low supplement use despite existing recommendations. The dietary causes of these deficiencies were noted to be poorly studied.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age and during pregnancy in Hong Kong, Indonesia, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, and Vietnam.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if periconceptional iron supplementation in young mothers affected malaria risk and iron status in their offspring.
results_summary: Iron supplementation did not alter child iron stores or malaria outcomes, but higher child iron stores and placental malaria increased parasitaemia risk. Chorioamnionitis was associated with reduced child parasitaemia.
population_specificity: Young mothers and their offspring in Burkina Faso.
effective_dosage: Weekly periconceptional iron supplementation (exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated, but outcomes were assessed at a median child age of 9 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if higher maternal education correlates with better adherence to iron-folic acid supplementation in Ethiopia.
results_summary: The study found that mothers with secondary education or higher had 2.89 times higher odds of adhering to iron-folic acid supplementation compared to those without formal education. The results suggest that maternal education improves adherence to supplementation.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Ethiopia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of zinc, not iron, in regulating host defense mechanisms and viral replication, with a focus on COVID-19.
results_summary: The abstract discusses zinc's biological importance, its role in immune function, and potential benefits against viral infections, but does not provide specific findings related to iron.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on zinc's role in human biology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cost-effectiveness of ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) versus other iron therapies (iron isomaltoside 1000, iron sucrose, and oral iron) in treating iron deficiency anemia in inflammatory bowel disease patients.
results_summary: FCM had the highest response rate (81%) and was cost-saving compared to IIM and IS, while being more effective but slightly more expensive than oral iron. FCM was projected as the most cost-effective intravenous iron therapy in Switzerland.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and iron deficiency anemia (IDA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how oral iron supplementation affects the gut microbiome by analyzing changes in volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in the faecal metabolome of patients with iron deficiency anaemia.
results_summary: The study analyzed stool samples from patients before and after iron treatment, focusing on iron-driven changes in VOCs, but specific results regarding efficacy or safety outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with iron deficiency anaemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between intractable anemia and Hirschsprung's disease (HD), focusing on the role of impaired iron absorption due to HD.
results_summary: The study found that intractable anemia in HD patients was poorly responsive to oral iron supplementation and blood transfusions, but surgical intervention effectively corrected anemia in all cases. The results suggest that HD may impair iron absorption, leading to persistent anemia.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (ages 11 years and 19 months) with intractable anemia and Hirschsprung's disease.
study_duration: Varied (6-year and 3-month histories of anemia prior to intervention)

study_goal: To compare the equivalence and assess the safety of oral iron supplements plus vitamin C versus oral iron supplements alone in patients with iron deficiency anemia (IDA).
results_summary: Oral iron supplements alone were equivalent to oral iron supplements plus vitamin C in improving hemoglobin recovery and iron absorption, with no significant differences in adverse event rates between the two groups. The study concluded that vitamin C supplements are not essential to take along with oral iron for IDA patients.
population_specificity: Adult patients with newly diagnosed iron deficiency anemia (mean age 38.3 years, 96.8% women).
effective_dosage: 100-mg oral iron tablet every 8 hours daily, with or without 200 mg of vitamin C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between proton pump inhibitors (PPIs)/histamine H2-receptor antagonists (H2As) and restless legs syndrome (RLS), particularly focusing on the role of iron deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that PPI/H2A use was associated with an increased risk of RLS in two large blood donor cohorts, independent of blood iron status. No evidence suggested that blood iron stores mediated this association.
population_specificity: Blood donors in the United States (N = 13,403) and Denmark (N = 50,323).
interactions: PPIs and H2As were noted to potentially contribute to iron deficiency, but no direct interactions with iron were discussed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the cost-effectiveness of two strategies to increase antenatal iron and folic acid supplementation (IFAS) and malaria chemoprophylaxis coverage among pregnant women in rural Côte d'Ivoire.
results_summary: The study will evaluate maternal post-partum anaemia and malaria infection as primary outcomes, along with adherence to supplementation and chemoprophylaxis, miscarriages, stillbirths, and low birth weight deliveries. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: 720 consenting pregnant women aged ≥15 years in the Taabo health and demographic surveillance system (HDSS) in south-central Côte d'Ivoire.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence, determinants, and maternal/foetal outcomes of iron deficiency anaemia among pregnant women with sickle cell disease (PWSCD).
results_summary: The prevalence of iron deficiency anaemia among PWSCD varied widely (6.67-83.33%), but evidence on associated factors and outcomes was inconclusive due to small sample sizes and varied study designs. The randomized trial reported no difference in outcomes between PWSCD who received iron supplementation and those who did not.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with sickle cell disease (PWSCD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore strategies for optimizing oral iron supplementation in athletes to improve iron absorption, reduce gastrointestinal side effects, and enhance treatment efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that oral iron supplementation is commonly used for iron-deficient athletes but often causes gastrointestinal side effects, leading to suboptimal treatment adherence. It suggests morning supplementation, ideally post-exercise, and alternate-day or lower doses for athletes with gut sensitivity as effective strategies.
population_specificity: Athletes with iron deficiency

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc supplementation, with and without iron, has beneficial or adverse effects on mental and motor development in children aged 0-5 years.
results_summary: The study found that zinc alone and zinc with iron co-supplementation did not show beneficial or adverse effects on child mental and motor development at 6 and 12 months of age, nor any long-term effects in preschool and school-age children. The evidence quality was low to moderate.
population_specificity: Children aged 0-5 years.
study_duration: Up to 12 months for some outcomes, with long-term follow-up to 9 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine micronutrient deficiencies, particularly iron, in patients who underwent laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and identify trends in supplementation recommendations.
results_summary: The study found that consistent iron supplementation is necessary for SG patients, alongside a multivitamin, to address deficiencies. The results suggest a clear need for iron supplementation post-SG, though specific efficacy details are not provided.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (SG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of iron supplementation on iron status and physiological performance after repeated blood donation in iron-replete individuals.
results_summary: Iron supplementation (20 mg and 80 mg daily) limited the negative effects of repeated blood donation on endurance performance (maximal power output and peak oxygen consumption) but did not prevent declines in iron status. The highest dose (80 mg) also mitigated effects on functional iron and iron metabolism regulation.
population_specificity: Moderately trained, iron-replete young men
study_duration: 28 days after each donation (three donations total, 3 months apart)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining vitamin D and iron supplementation, compared to vitamin D alone, could improve bone turnover, inflammatory, oxidative stress, and metabolic markers in women with iron deficiency and vitamin D insufficiency.
results_summary: Iron-vitamin D co-supplementation did not show added benefits for improving bone turnover, inflammatory, oxidative stress, or metabolic markers compared to vitamin D alone. Vitamin D alone had some detrimental effects on inflammatory and metabolic markers, while iron supplementation improved certain hematological parameters.
population_specificity: 87 women aged 18-45 years with hemoglobin ≤ 12.7 g/dL and 25OHD ≤ 29 ng/mL (vitamin D deficiency/insufficiency).
effective_dosage: 27 mg/day iron plus 1000 IU/day vitamin D3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intravenous iron supplementation improves fatigue and general health in non-anemic repeat adult blood donors with iron deficiency (ferritin ≤ 50 µg/L).
results_summary: Intravenous iron supplementation significantly increased ferritin and hemoglobin levels but had no effect on fatigue or general well-being compared to placebo. No group differences were observed for clinical and safety outcomes.
population_specificity: Non-anemic repeat adult blood donors with iron deficiency (ferritin ≤ 50 µg/L).
effective_dosage: Single intravenous dose of 800 mg iron-carboxymaltose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether iron deficiency is an independent risk factor for functional impairment, fatigue, and rehabilitation progress in older hospitalized patients, and whether iron supplementation improves functional performance.
results_summary: Iron deficiency was associated with fatigue and poor functional recovery, but iron supplementation improved knee extension strength. Comorbidity, iron deficiency, and changes in handgrip strength were major predictors of poor improvement in functional status.
population_specificity: Older hospitalized patients (65-95 years, 67% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the best current management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), including the role of iron supplementation as an additional therapy.
results_summary: The abstract mentions iron supplementation as one of the additional therapies discussed, but no specific results regarding its effects are provided.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), particularly in the African context.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of nutrition-sensitive and nutrition-specific interventions, including iron supplementation, on hemoglobin concentrations and anemia across different population groups.
results_summary: Daily and intermittent iron supplementation, along with other interventions like micronutrient powders and delayed cord clamping, were associated with increased hemoglobin concentrations in children under 5 years, older children, and pregnant women, as well as reduced anemia risk. The study highlighted the effectiveness of nutrition-specific interventions but noted a lack of evidence for nutrition-sensitive approaches.
population_specificity: Children aged <5 years, school-age children, and pregnant women.
effective_dosage: Not specified (daily and intermittent iron supplementation mentioned without dosage details).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if untargeted iron supplementation poses potential harm and to compare the effects of two forms of iron (ferrous sulfate and ferrous bisglycinate) versus placebo.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results; it describes the study design and planned measurements, including ferritin concentrations and markers of potential harm in blood and stool.
population_specificity: Non-pregnant women aged 18-45 years in Cambodia.
effective_dosage: 60 mg elemental iron as ferrous sulfate or 18 mg ferrous bisglycinate, administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association of vitamin D status with inflammation, iron biomarkers, and anemia following blunt trauma.
results_summary: Trauma patients had higher inflammation and hepcidin levels, lower vitamin D and iron levels, and increased bone marrow erythroferrone expression compared to hip replacement patients. Vitamin D status correlated with systemic inflammation, iron dysfunction, and persistent injury-associated anemia.
population_specificity: Blunt trauma patients (n = 45), elective hip replacement patients (n = 22), and healthy controls (n = 8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of intravenous ferric derisomaltose/iron isomaltoside 1000 versus oral ferrous fumarate in preventing iron deficiency anaemia in pregnant women with persistent iron deficiency after initial treatment.
results_summary: The study found that both intravenous and oral iron treatments were evaluated for preventing iron deficiency anaemia, with primary endpoints focusing on haemoglobin levels and other haematological indices. Secondary outcomes included clinical symptom improvements and adverse events, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Pregnant women between 14 and 21 weeks of gestation with persistent iron deficiency after 4 weeks of standard oral iron treatment.
effective_dosage: Single 1000 mg dose of intravenous ferric derisomaltose/iron isomaltoside 1000 or 100 mg oral ferrous fumarate (containing 60 mg ascorbic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the regulatory mechanisms and pathophysiology of iron deficiency in chronic kidney disease (CKD) and heart failure (HF) populations, and evaluate the effects of intravenous (IV) and oral iron supplementation in HF.
results_summary: The study found that IV iron supplementation in HF patients showed symptomatic benefits but no effect on clinical outcomes, while also posing potential risks of myocardial and endothelial damage due to reactive oxygen species. Newer oral iron preparations were noted to lack similar toxicity concerns and may be beneficial in HF.
population_specificity: Heart failure (HF) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of preoperative recombinant human erythropoietin (rHuEPO) therapy combined with iron supplementation in reducing the need for allogeneic red blood cell transfusions in anaemic adults undergoing non-cardiac surgery.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative rHuEPO + iron therapy reduced the need for RBC transfusions and increased preoperative haemoglobin concentrations at higher doses, but did not decrease the mean number of RBC units transfused per patient. No significant differences were observed in adverse events, mortality, or hospital stay length.
population_specificity: Preoperatively anaemic adults undergoing non-cardiac surgery, primarily in orthopaedic, gastrointestinal, and gynaecological specialties.
effective_dosage: Iron supplementation (enteral or parenteral) combined with rHuEPO at low (150-300 IU/kg) or high (500-600 IU/kg) doses.
study_duration: Varied across trials, ranging from once weekly to daily, or a 5-to-10-day period; one trial administered rHuEPO on the morning of surgery and for five days postoperatively.

study_goal: To assess the efficacy and safety of iron supplementation for perioperative anemia in geriatric patients with hip fracture.
results_summary: Iron supplementation was not associated with reducing blood transfusion rate but was linked to reduced transfusion volume and shorter hospital stays, particularly with preoperative intravenous use of 200-300 mg iron. Data were insufficient for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Geriatric patients undergoing hip fracture surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the successful surgical treatment of intussusception in a patient with BRBNS, including postoperative iron supplementation.
results_summary: The patient received oral iron supplementation postoperatively, and the intervention was associated with an uneventful recovery and no recurrence of intussusception during follow-up.
population_specificity: A 33-year-old Chinese male with BRBNS complicated by intussusception.
effective_dosage: Oral iron supplementation for 2 weeks (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of timing (morning vs. afternoon) and frequency (consecutive, alternate, or every third day) of oral iron dosing on fractional iron absorption (FIA) and plasma hepcidin (PHep) levels in infants.
results_summary: Morning and afternoon iron doses were comparably absorbed, consecutive dosing increased PHep and modestly decreased absorption compared to alternate-day dosing, and alternate-day or every-third-day dosing did not increase PHep or decrease absorption.
population_specificity: Kenyan infants, 65.7% of whom were anemic.
effective_dosage: 12 mg iron (as micronutrient powder or supplement), given in varying frequencies (morning/afternoon, consecutive/alternate/every third day).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of Lacticaseibacillus paracasei on sperm vitality and motility in mice, as well as its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Lacticaseibacillus paracasei increased sperm motility by 30-40% and enhanced mitochondrial activity through factors like AMPK and SIRT1, improving sperm vitality and function.
population_specificity: Mature sperm from the caudal vas deferens of mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lacticaseibacillus paracasei MSMC39-1, in combination with Bifidobacterium animalis TA-1, could lower risk factors associated with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The probiotics group showed significant reductions in LDL-cholesterol, body weight, BMI, waist circumference, systolic blood pressure, and total cholesterol compared to placebo, along with changes in gut microbiome diversity and predicted metabolic functions.
population_specificity: 58 participants with risk factors for metabolic syndrome (mean age ~42-44 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of L. paracasei K56, prebiotics (XOS, GOS, PG), and their synbiotic combinations on metabolism and gut microbiota in children with obesity using an in vitro fermentation model.
results_summary: The study found that GOS and XOS had higher degradation rates than PG + K56 synbiotics, and treatments with XOS + K56 and GOS + K56 significantly reduced gas production and altered gut microbiota composition by increasing Bifidobacteria and Lactobacilli while reducing Escherichia/Shigella.
population_specificity: 14 children with obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the protective effects of live and heat-killed Lacticaseibacillus paracasei 6235 on ulcerative colitis in a mouse model.
results_summary: Both live and heat-killed L. paracasei 6235 mitigated colitis damage, improved tight junction protein levels, restored colon morphology, and modulated inflammatory responses via MAPK and NF-κB pathways. Heat-killed L. paracasei 6235 showed additional benefits in modulating intestinal microbiota through lipid metabolic pathways.
population_specificity: DSS-induced colitis mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the probiotic properties of Lacticaseibacillus paracasei NCU-04 and its effects on loperamide-induced constipation in mice, including its impact on gut microbiota and depression-like behaviors.
results_summary: L. paracasei NCU-04 improved defecation-related indicators, reduced colon inflammation, modulated gut microbiota diversity, and alleviated depression-like behaviors in constipated mice, likely through the microbiota-gut-brain axis.
population_specificity: Loperamide-induced constipated mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Lacticaseibacillus paracasei in an extruded sorghum beverage on body composition, lipid profiles, and intestinal health in overweight and obese adults.
results_summary: The study found that the beverage containing L. paracasei improved body composition (visceral fat and waist volume), lipid profiles (Castelli index I), and intestinal health (Bristol scale, diarrhea score, valeric acid, and L. paracasei DNA concentration). No changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the primary components of Lacticaseibacillus paracasei ET-22 postbiotics responsible for inhibiting oral malodor and examine their effects on biofilms and volatile sulfur compound (VSC) production.
results_summary: The study found that cell-free supernatants (CFSs) of ET-22, particularly phenyllactic acid (PLA) and peptide GP(Hyp)GAG, significantly reduced VSC production by 42.7% and 44.6%, respectively, and suppressed biofilm biomass and thickness. These components also reduced the abundance of odor-producing bacteria and downregulated biofilm-forming and VSC-producing genes.
population_specificity: Sufferers with halitosis (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: To investigate the effect of live Lacticaseibacillus paracasei N1115 on immune pathway activation and its subsequent impact on primary hippocampal neuron development in vitro.
results_summary: Lacticaseibacillus paracasei N1115 significantly activated macrophage immune function, increasing cytokine expression (IL-6 and TNF-α) and promoting hippocampal neuron viability, synaptic gene expression (SYP, PSD95), and morphological development (neurite length, branching points). The effects were stronger than peptidoglycan but weaker than LPS.
population_specificity: In vitro primary hippocampal neurons and RAW264.7 macrophage cells.
